title: Visualization
text:
Day 2 Visualization
Aim of the day:
  Provisional list   - Assess the quality of a scientific plot.
- Copy and improve a graph using ggplot2.
- Gather plots using patchwork.
- make some (Complex)Heatmaps.
- annotate with statistics (ggpubr).
- automate the graphic generation.

title: Visualization
text:
Outline

graphics: The good, the bad and the ugly
Personalize
One graphic to gather them all
Adding statistics and automate graphs

title: Visualization
text:
What and why ?
A scientific visualization is a graphical interface between people and data.
- There are many possible graphics for the same data.
- Different people perceive theses graphics differently.
 An advanced graph :
- Conveys complex information clearly
- Integrates multiple layers of information
- Is reproducible and adaptable by code
- Is aesthetically pleasing and follows conventions

title: Visualization
text:
The 10 rules of good graphs



Rule 1: Know your audience. (collaborators, journal readers …).
Rule 2: Identify the role of the figure (⇒ geometry).
Rule 3: Adapt to the medium (paper, poster, projection screen …).
Rule 4: Captions are not optional.
Rule 5: never trust the defaults (size, font, colors …): good enough for any, best for none.

Rule 6: Use color effectively & only when needed.
Rule 7: Do Not Mislead the Reader (see examples below).
- As a rule of thumb, use the simplest type of plots
Rule 8: Avoid “Chartjunk” (see examples below).
  Rule 9: Message trumps beauty.
Rule 10: Get the right tool (here R + tidyverse + ggplot)

Additionally:
- seek external opinion.
- ensure reproducibility with your code.
- know the domain’s best practices.

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
YAML
---
title: "Document title"
author: "Lewis Forwarder"
output: html_document
---

Starts with ---, ends with ---
Intuitive syntax \(\rightarrow\) field: value
Outputs: HTML, docx, pptx, (pdf)

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Markdown
Intuitive language to write, in plain text, a document that is transformed into a report (in Rstudio, go to submenu “Help > Markdown Quick Reference” for a quick tour).

Emphasis
*italic*   **bold**
_italic_   __bold__
Headers
# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

Unordered List
* Item 1
* Item 2
    + Item 2a
    + Item 2b

Ordered List
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
    + Item 3a
    + Item 3b

And so much more!

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
R Chunks
Your code goes in “R chunks”1.



```{r chunk title, echo = TRUE}
hist(rnorm(100))
```











Customization:

Beginners: ⚙️,
Intermediate users: go here,
Advanced users: Yi Hui’s website.


click on “+c” to insert a chunk quickly

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Other features

PDF: \(\LaTeX\)
Maths: \(\LaTeX\)
Customized HTML documents: CSS (ou SCSS)
Diagrams: mermaid or GraphViz
Other high-level programming languages: Python, Julia, SQL
Other: bash, Rcpp (C++), Stan (Bayesian statistics), etc.

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Most useful fields

title: title of the document
author: your name
output:

html_document \(\rightarrow\) is the easiest to use
word_document \(\rightarrow\) is very convenient
pdf_document \(\rightarrow\) requires \(\LaTeX\)

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text: In this workshop, you will reproduce Figure 2 from (Ong et al. 2020) (from the cleaned data located here) and write a short report explaining your choices, results, and limitations.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
The Figure
Figure 2 contains three sub-panels:

a clustered heatmap with sample annotations,
longitudinal expression profiles for inflammatory genes,
longitudinal expression profiles for T-cell markers.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Detailed instructions
Work in groups of 3–4.
Start with each subfigure individually to break up your workload. For example:

create a project,
save the dataset (located here) in the project’s folder and load it in the environment,
reproduce first the subfigure showing the expression profile of IL1A with ggplot2,
create a function from the previous code that takes as input the name of the gene and outputs the figure,
create subpanels B and C with patchwork,
work on reproducing the heatmap with ComplexHeatmap,
combine everything in one big panel.

Write your comments describing your work in an R Mardown document, with an HTML output, breaking down the steps.
At the end of the day, present your work: what you achieved, where you had difficulties, the questions you had. We will show you our own version.

title: Introduction and Reminders
text:
Schedule, language, etc

Day 1: tips and tricks of dplyr and ggplot2. Create a report in R Markdown.
Day 2: Heatmaps, and other advanced graphical representations. Create panels of plots. Good practices in data visualization.
Day 3: work on your data.

title: Great Tables
text:
Great tables

Source: https://gt.rstudio.com/

title: Great Tables
text:
Simulated example

set.seed(73)
dat.ex <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(100),
  f = gl(n = 2, k = 50, labels = c("A", "B")),
  y = -5*x + 10*as.numeric(f) + rnorm(100)
)

title: Great Tables
text:
Using gt with gtsummary



tbl_summary(dat.ex, by = f)

  lm(y ~ x * f,
     data = dat.ex))

title: Great Tables
text:
Exercise level 1

Create your own toy dataset.
Use gt and/or gtsummary to create tables on your toy dataset.
Create a short R Markdown report with your data, a plot, and a beautiful table.
